comparison.Price: The Model X starts at $10,000 less than the Yukon Denali, offering immediate upfront savings.
comparison.Mileage Average: While the Model X operates on electricity, the Yukon Denali uses gasoline. The Model X's efficiency in terms of Wh/mile can translate to further savings in the long run.
comparison.Annual Miles: This is kept constant to make a fair comparison between the two vehicles.
comparison.Annual Fuel: The Model X consumes electricity, whereas the Yukon Denali consumes gasoline. The difference in fuel type can lead to cost disparities.
comparison.Fuel/Electricity Cost: The cost of electricity is significantly lower than that of premium gasoline, leading to annual savings for Model X owners.
comparison.Annual Energy/Fuel Costs: The Model X's electricity costs are significantly less than the Yukon Denali's fuel costs, resulting in substantial annual savings.
comparison.Brake System/Cost: The Model X uses regenerative braking, which reduces wear on the brakes and can lead to longer brake life and fewer replacements.
comparison.Annual Costs: Overall, the Model X has slightly lower annual costs compared to the Yukon Denali.
comparison.Three-Year Costs: Over a span of three years, the costs remain the same for both vehicles, but considering other benefits like the environment, the Model X is a better choice.
comparison.Resale Value After 3 Years: The Model X retains a higher resale value after 3 years compared to the Yukon Denali, ensuring a better return on investment.
comparison.Three-Year Cost Per Mile: The Model X offers a more economical cost per mile over three years, nearly 38% cheaper than the Yukon Denali.
